tags: try and grow out of it
or at least learn to shut up.
summary: Reminder to the Trollboys out there that no one takes you seriously when it comes to your hate on Captain Marvel because of how...
body:
Reminder to the Trollboys out there that no one takes you seriously when it comes to your hate on Captain Marvel because of how pathetic most of your arguments are.

Also, Brie Larson is so much better than you people - and that’s without her even trying to be. Then again, it really isn’t all that hard to be better than you.

summary: How That Extra Two Minutes Went Down In The Marvel Writer Room
title: How That Extra Two Minutes Went Down In The Marvel Writer Room
body:
Russo Brothers: There all done.
Writers: Good lets film it
*Films movie*
Russo Brothers: Aw shit we forgot to add this two minutes in the ending!
Writers: Ah man!
Russo Brothers: Let's wait until it gets released and wait a few months, let's say june then we come at the fans and say on Twitter, 'Hey btw we are releasing Endgame for two extra minutes!'
Writers and Russo Brothers: *High Five*

Nicole Maines as Nial Nal from “Supergirl”, TV’s first trans superhero.

summary: I work in a Target as a phone specialist, so I’m in the electronics department all day, listening to the same music spots and...
body:
I work in a Target as a phone specialist, so I’m in the electronics department all day, listening to the same music spots and movie ads over and over again on both the TV wall AND a billboard-like preview screen above the book section. So this stuff gets old very quickly. Even the bits I like, it’s not so much I “enjoy” them as it is I don’t want to actively claw my eyes out when they play. Even the different Captain Marvel spots are little more than a couple minutes of zero irritation floating at the back of my mind.

Until earlier this week, when a tiny boy that couldn’t have been older than a year and a half, maybe two years old, noticed the Captain Marvel movie/companion book ad on the big screen. His eyes lit up and he punched his fist into the air in his best superhero pose, giving a little “raahhh!” as he tried to copy the moves Carol was doing onscreen. This went on for the duration of the ad, this little boy hopping around and waving his arms like he was fighting off bad guys, like I’ve seen other kids do when they see Superman or Spider-Man. I was grinning like an idiot the entire time.

And even later, a woman came up to buy something from the desk with her son in the basket of her cart, probably seven or eight years old. She began her transaction as the same CM spot came on, and the boy twisted around to watch it, chanting “Cap-tain Mar-vel! Cap-tain Mar-vel!”, something that would have been super irritating if I wasn’t so over-the-moon about not one but two little boys outwardly adoring this badass superhero. It didn’t matter to them that she was a woman - she’s strong and fast and has laser fists and is awesome, just like all the other superheroes that they love. It’s so refreshing to see young boys idolizing an incredible woman, and it’s a sight I will never take for granted.

I work in a Target as a phone specialist, so I’m in the electronics department all day, listening to the same music spots and movie ads over and over again on both the TV wall AND a billboard-like preview screen above the book section. So this stuff gets old very quickly. Even the bits I like, it’s not so much I “enjoy” them as it is I don’t want to actively claw my eyes out when they play. Even the different Captain Marvel spots are little more than a couple minutes of zero irritation floating at the back of my mind.

Until earlier this week, when a tiny boy that couldn’t have been older than a year and a half, maybe two years old, noticed the Captain Marvel movie/companion book ad on the big screen. His eyes lit up and he punched his fist into the air in his best superhero pose, giving a little “raahhh!” as he tried to copy the moves Carol was doing onscreen. This went on for the duration of the ad, this little boy hopping around and waving his arms like he was fighting off bad guys, like I’ve seen other kids do when they see Superman or Spider-Man. I was grinning like an idiot the entire time.

And even later, a woman came up to buy something from the desk with her son in the basket of her cart, probably seven or eight years old. She began her transaction as the same CM spot came on, and the boy twisted around to watch it, chanting “Cap-tain Mar-vel! Cap-tain Mar-vel!”, something that would have been super irritating if I wasn’t so over-the-moon about not one but two little boys outwardly adoring this badass superhero. It didn’t matter to them that she was a woman - she’s strong and fast and has laser fists and is awesome, just like all the other superheroes that they love. It’s so refreshing to see young boys idolizing an incredible woman, and it’s a sight I will never take for granted.

title: Captain Marvel
body:
Why I would say our dearest Captain Mar-Vel doesn’t sit well with some viewers (barring any sexist pre-conceived hatred). 

It doesn’t follow the traditional formula. (a lot of this is taken from the honest trailer for the MCU). 

1. Carol doesn’t use humor as a weapon. - she seems to say things because she genuinely finds them funny herself. I think this is why it feels so different from the other leads in Marvel. She doesn’t use it as a defense or posturing move. 

1.5 No dick measuring - this goes along with her humor, and also in how her final battle concludes. ‘I don’t need to prove anything to you.’ The other Avengers spend a lot of time proving themselves to others. (Thor has to prove himself to a hammer… consistently). 

2. Not successful in pre-hero life - Carol had a family and a job, even as a Kree she seems to be content with her team and mission and only looking for answers about her past, not her purpose. 

3. No romance subplot

4. More than one friend - Who also happen to be more than one person of color as an important character. (excluding Black Panther obviously). 

5. Carol does not fit into the preset hero categories of a tough military stereotype or fast-talking quip master very neatly. She is both and neither. (see 1 and 1.5)

6. She doesn’t start out as an anti-hero/selfish jerk - she is always a hero, as a member of the airforce, and as a Kree, she thought she was working to protect people.

7. No dad figure -  Yon Rogg is an antagonist, but he isn’t very father-figure-ish. His relationship with her feels more pseudo-romantic and even Frankenstein to his Monster. Someone trying to play god and loses control of his creation when it develops autonomy. Carol’s actual father isn’t even a big part of her past. 

7.5 No dad figure - Fury is clearly her buddy cop. He is a supervisor to the other Avengers, but Carol and he operate like partners.

8. The villain is not just a bad version of the hero - The Supreme Intelligence is an ideology a corrupt system with a mouthpiece. Unlike other villains who are perpetuating a bad system or fighting against one that the hero perpetuates, The Supreme Intelligence is the bad system itself trying to maintain it’s status quo.

summary: (1/2) from what i understand, it's mostly men that don't like her bc she openly speaks about issues in the film industry (ie the...
question: (1/2) from what i understand, it's mostly men that don't like her bc she openly speaks about issues in the film industry (ie the fact that most critics are white men, who cant relate to a film that wasn't made for them like the people who it was made for, like a wrinkle in time, or about demanding to have female and poc reporters ask questions/interview her), the thing about the cast not liking her mostly came from an interview with Hemsworth, where they made dry jokes with each other
answer: Great so nothing with relevance. See I thought the hate steamed from something she did. I thought I had to consider cancelling her. Those reasons just make me love her more. We stan a queen, that is Brianne Larson.

reblog.comment: Great so nothing with relevance. See I thought the hate steamed from something she did. I thought I had to consider cancelling her. Those reasons just make me love her more. We stan a queen, that is Brianne Larson.

If the sun is down I’m probably looking at the stars. My blog is basically the hot mess of my love for the marvel cinematic universe, various tv shows, movies and video games. All original content under #my edit .

summary: Just today I saw people shipping Carol with: Maria Rambeau, Valkyrie, Jessica Jones, War Machine, Thor and Spider-Man. I mean......
question: Just today I saw people shipping Carol with: Maria Rambeau, Valkyrie, Jessica Jones, War Machine, Thor and Spider-Man. I mean... do people understand the concept of friendship? 😂 damn...
answer:
I will take this anon’s question to answer others of the same subject: do you ship Carol with someone? And my answer is nope! lol

But it’s a free world guys, let people ship their hearts out 😂

I understand shipping is part of this “fandom life”, and I respect them all. It’s just that for me, In my eyes, I don’t see these relationships as “romantic”.

I love Maria and Carol relationship in the movie and I absolutely adore Jessica Drew* and Carol in the comics … but all I see there is a powerful/strong/real friendship between women, which for me, personally, is even better than any romance.

Oh, and the only reason I’m just bringing these two names to my answer is that they’re the two characters I’ve been asked the most about and this is already long enough lol ;)

blog.title: Proud creator of stupid stories (also other stuff)
blog.description: I'm Charles, I'm a nerd who likes writing and overanalyzing stuff. Contact me for writing commissions, questions, job offers, etc, on oberonn.business@gmail.com if you're interested in what I do.

tags: i think i don't remember if punisher sells well
iron man is selling poorly relatively speaking
which is an embarrassment considering tony stark is up there with superman when it comes to recognizability
summary: @Marvel Comics, instead of cancelling all of your underselling books only to reboot them with the same authors 3 months later,...
body:
@Marvel Comics, instead of cancelling all of your underselling books only to reboot them with the same authors 3 months later, how about you hire some new talent and give them a shot with established characters?

Underselling books and titles doesn’t have to be a failure. It can be an opportunity to experiment and try out new things to see if they stick. If they don’t, it doesn’t matter because the book was selling poorly anyway. If it succeeds, then you found a new seller to add to your regular releases.

It doesn’t have to be a whole ongoing series or even a miniseries. It can be one issue. Or even one short story in an anthology series.

Think about it.

Also if you end up doing it or something like it, hmu.
